steps.text: Become certified in Food Manufacturing, Processing and Storage Pest Control - Classification 7.
Pass the general standards exam.
Study materials in 'A Guide for Private and Commercial Applicators: Applying Pesticides Correctly'.
Pass the exam based on this manual and Arkansas Pest Control Law.
Obtain study materials from the Arkansas State Plant Board.
Acknowledge sources of additional information.
Check pesticide information for currency.
Ensure intended use aligns with product label.
Integrate chemical, physical, cultural, and biological controls for pest management in food processing facilities.
Use pesticides as a last resort.
Construct a well-built building.
Implement preventive design and maintenance.
Implement daily pest management programs for food plants.
Maintain records as part of the program.
Address pests in facility.
Manage pests from surrounding areas.
Monitor incoming materials for pests.
The applicator must be aware of federal and state regulations.
Check regulations from FDA, USDA-FSIS, EPA, OSHA, DOT, Arkansas State Plant Board, ADH, and ADEQ.
Proper engineering design is implemented for pest prevention.
Maintain short grass and trim shrubs.
Pave access areas.
Ensure proper drainage.
Place an 18- to 24-inch strip of gravel around the foundation.
Position night-lights at least 30 feet away from doors.
Maintain a minimum distance of 4 inches between framing and walls.
Fill any necessary voids with materials such as polyurethane foam.
Coat concrete floors for improved sanitation.
Use acid-proof or brick floors in wet processing areas.

Easy to clean wall materials.
Seal hollow panel-type walls.
Check that roofs are smooth and free of standing water.
Inspect pitch and gravel or corrugated metal roofs for insect harboring.
Use few windows with transparent glass.
Choose metal tight-fitting doors.
Install air curtains at large doors.
Install dust-tight fixtures for good lighting.
Provide electrical and plumbing services for easy access and cleaning.

Equipment should be roomy and accessible for cleaning.
Equipment should be raised at least six inches off the floor or sealed to it.

Eliminate litter, waste, and uncut grass.

Ensure proper drainage.

Maintain housekeeping.

Use chemical repellents and avicides where appropriate.
Rodent-proof all openings.

Next step in the process.
Review existing activities.
Compile a list of deficiencies.
The committee should wear identifiable uniforms.
Carry necessary tools: flashlights and scrapers.
Thoroughly inspect new places.
Do not just focus on areas with a history of problems.

Distribute notes to department heads.
Departments should correct defects immediately.
Committee meets to review notes, address uncorrected items, and assign realistic correction dates.
Start by looking in obscure places.

Consider potential interactions with the facility's practices.

Determine if the larva has legs on its back half.
Adult beetles have chewing mouthparts and feed on food products.
Adult moths have sucking mouthparts and do not feed on solid food but can contaminate products.

Examine forewings for brown-gray color.
Inspect larvae for dirty white color.

Examine wings for pale gray color and wavy black markings.

Inspect grains for damage caused by adults and larvae.
Identify the presence of a small, oval, reddish-brown beetle with a humped appearance.

constraints.text: User is responsible for ensuring safe and consistent use with product label.
Maintain records as part of the daily pest management program.
Address pests not only within the facility but also from surrounding areas and incoming materials.
Place gravel around foundation to discourage rodents.

Preventing pest problems.

Pests have different moisture requirements.
Processed goods typically have low moisture levels.
Temperatures below 65°F or above 95°F are unfavorable for most insects and molds.
Avoid rapid temperature drops.
Not all pests have effective commercial pheromones available.
Residual applications are permitted only in specified areas.
Application to food areas must be limited to cracks, crevices, expansion joints, and voids.
Food product must not contain unapproved substances or residues above tolerance levels.
Applying a pesticide to a site not listed on its label is illegal.
USDA approval is a requirement for using pesticides in federally inspected meat plants.
Residuals cannot be used in production areas where they might be carried in.
Ensure safety of other workers, facility employees, and food product.
* Only proceed if Mediterranean Flour Moth is present.
Proceed with caution when handling larvae due to silken threads.
High moisture conditions present.
Infestation of Foreign Grain Beetles indicates need for immediate action.
* Warning: Be careful when handling cockroaches as they can carry diseases.

Compare old and new droppings to determine age.
Do not use where it might contaminate food.
Be aware of fire or explosion hazard.
Respirators for pesticides must be approved by MSHA and NIOSH.
